body:
After using Samsung Galaxy S2 for about two years, I was convinced that all android apps have this nice, subtle, noise texture on all gradient and flat UI elements.

Here is a picture of android keyboard on S2, although a bad iPhone camera gives a bit more emphasis on the granularity.

It was surprising and a bit unnerving to see the same apps on Nexus 5. All those smooth, gliding gradients kept bringing up memories like upgrading a video card of an old 486 computer and for the first time running Windows 95 in 16 bit color mode.

Super Amoled display works by having each pixel represented by three light emitting sub-pixels (Red, Green, Blue). Those sub-pixels have more limited lifespan than a typical light source of traditional back-lit screens. The balance between their lifespan and intensity is very delicate, apparently making it very hard to display a consistent color or gradient across multiple pixels.

Ignoring the difference in resolution, the graininess is still very visible on Galaxy S2 (left) vs Nexus 5 (right).

Nexus 5 comes with IPS screen and although I miss S2's black colors (when pixel is completely off and no light emitted at all), the smooth gradients, higher resolution and just overall a healthy looking screen of Nexus 5 is an amazing upgrade.
